page.title: 16LANDSCAPE
page.content: The land in this area is vary good for arable farming. This is because it is mainly flat and has been derived from river alluvium and sedementary bed rock. Machinery has little trouble from wet land or steep slopes. The streams coming from the villages all drain into the River Trent. This then flows into the Humber and into the North Sea. Very little erosion takes place. In fact the only erosion is that of the wind blowing loose surface soils off the fields, but this does not create any problem. The old villages each had a woodland area. This is why small stands of trees can be seen as well as the established woods of Gamston and Eaton. These all act as a haven for wildlife and game birds.
